quoteFirst: “The Aboukir,” says the report, “was struck at about
quoteLast: on the starboard beam. The Hogue and Cressy closed, and took up a position, the Hogue ahead of the Aboukir, and the Cressy about four hundred yards on her port beam. As soon as it was seen that Aboukir was in danger of sinking, all the boats were sent away from the Cressy, and a picket boat was hoisted out without steam up.
title: History of the World War, Volume 2 (of 7)
author: March, Francis A., Jr., 1863-1928; Beamish, Richard J. (Richard Joseph), 1867-1945; Hare, James H., 1856-1946 [Photographer]; Thompson, Donald C., 1885-1947 [Photographer]

quoteFirst: A better night’s rest could not be asked for than the one I enjoyed till the _train de luxe_ pulled up in the Lyons station at
title: Roundabout to Moscow: An Epicurean Journey
author: Bouton, John Bell, 1830-1902

quoteFirst: The bugles sounded the advance and, with a cheer, our whole line moved forward down the gentle slope; quickening their pace as the enemy retired before them, and still keeping up a heavy fire towards the clump of trees that concealed the Dervish camp from sight. The enemy's fire had now died out. At
quoteLast: the "cease fire" was sounded and, as the troops advanced, it was evident that resistance was at an end.
title: With Kitchener in the Soudan: A Story of Atbara and Omdurman

quoteLast: , Merriam sank, exhausted but immaculate, into an easy chair and lit a cigarette, in an effort to compose his nerves and regain the _sang froid_ he needed for his imminent rôle of a particularly debonair senator of the United States acting as host to a brilliant dinner party.
title: Mollie's Substitute Husband
author: McConn, Max, 1881-

quoteFirst: As the British force advanced, the infantry in echelon, the Brigade of Guards leading and the cavalry on the right, the enemy was observed abandoning his earthworks at Mahuta, and falling back along the railway line to Mahsameh. His railway trains were all seen moving off in the same direction. At
quoteLast: the British artillery came into action with the Egyptian infantry and guns posted on the Canal bank to the west of Mahuta.
title: The Egyptian campaigns, 1882 to 1885
author: Royle, Charles, 1882-1936

quoteFirst: Of course Mr. Gwillam wasn’t as mad as that; but it was certain that he must have delusions because of his believing about the end of the world coming at
quoteLast: on a Friday, and about our going up into the skies on a whirlwind. And it was a delusion for him to believe that Dame Trueman had bewitched him.
title: Mary Jane Married: Tales of a Village Inn
author: Sims, George R. (George Robert), 1847-1922

quoteLast: The Battalion scouts, who had previously gone forward to reconnoitre, had just returned and reported that all had gone well with the Post Office Rifles, who were holding all their objectives, and that the stream beyond, which we had to cross, was practically dry and offered no obstacle.
title: The History of the Prince of Wales' Civil Service Rifles
